clinical_study.brief_title: Role of Obstructive Sleep Apnea Syndrome in the Occurrence of Diabetic Retinopathy in Type 2 Diabetes.
clinical_study.official_title: Role of Obstructive Sleep Apnea Syndrome in the Occurrence of Diabetic Retinopathy in Type 2 Diabetes.

brief_summary.textblock:
Diabetic retinopathy (DR) is the most common visual complication of diabetes. Risk factors for developing DR are diabetes duration, glycemic control, and hypertension . The prevalence ranges from 17 to 61% according to the diabetes duration .
Obstructive sleep apnea syndrome (OSAS) is very frequent in Type 2 Diabetes population, reaching a prevalence of 23-48% .
Few is known about the exact role of OSAS in the development of DR. A recent study has shown that OSAS is an independent predictor for the progression to pre-/proliferative DR. The purpose of the present study is to assess if the presence of OSA in diabetic patients is a predictive factor for DR occurrence.

primary_outcome.measure: Presence of obstructive sleep apnea in diabetic patients is a predictive factor for diabetic retinopathy occurence
primary_outcome.description: obstructive sleep apnea is defined as apnea-hypopnea index > 15 on polysomnography

secondary_outcome.measure: Correlation between severity of obstructive sleep apnea and presence of diabetic retinopathy

arm_group.description: diabetic patiens with other/multiple ocular disorder(s)

intervention.description: classical polysomnography non invasive measurement of blood pressure blood test: determination of HbA1c, glucose, C-peptide, hemoglobin, white blood cell count, trombocytes

study_pop.textblock: All patients with a diagnosis of diabetes type I or type II who went to a ocular screening visit to assess ocular complications associated with diabetes are asked to undergo an in-lab polysomnography..

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- presence of diabetic type II
- able to undergo an in-lab polysomnography
Exclusion Criteria:
- known presence of obstructive sleep apnea and treated by CPAP
